intro: Hey there, young scientists! Let's explore how heat moves around. Get ready to see heat in action!

questions.question: Imagine you're holding a hot mug of cocoa. Where does the heat energy go?
options: It flows from the mug to your hands.
It flows from your hands to the mug.
questions.hint: Think about what happens to your hands and the cocoa when you hold it for a while.

questions.question: Heat always flows from an object with a temperature that is:
questions.hint: Remember our analogy of water flowing downhill!

questions.question: If you put a cold spoon into hot soup, what happens to the heat energy?
options: The soup gets hotter and the spoon gets colder.
The heat moves from the spoon to the soup.
The heat moves from the soup to the spoon.
The heat stays where it is.
questions.hint: What do you think makes the spoon eventually feel warm?

questions.question: When two objects with different temperatures are in contact, they will keep exchanging heat until:
options: One object becomes very hot and the other very cold.
Both objects reach the same temperature.
The hotter object runs out of heat.
questions.hint: This state where everything is the same temperature is called thermal equilibrium.

followups: Great job exploring how heat moves! It's like a natural rule that energy likes to spread out.
Understanding heat flow helps us understand many things, like why we wear sweaters in winter!
summary: Heat energy naturally flows from hotter objects to colder objects until they reach the same temperature.
